## Table of contents

## Systeme Internationale or 'SI' units

All quantities in physics have a unit which has been agreed on internationally. There are six fundamental quantities that can be used to define or derive any other quantity. These are known as base quantities.

- **kilogram**, kg &mdash; mass
- **metre**, m &mdash; length
- **second**, s &mdash; time
- **kelvin**, k &mdash; temperature
- **ampere**, A &mdash; current
- **mole**, mol &mdash; amount

<Callout emoji="âš¡ï¸">
  There is also a seventh SI unit &mdash; the candela (cd) &mdash; which is used
  to measure luminous intensity.
</Callout>

All other quantiies, such as energy or force, are based upon these quantities. It must be possible to express their units in terms of base quantity units (kg, m, etc.)

To change **SI units** into **base SI units**, you simply need to think of an equation containing base quantities &mdash; for example, changing newton (N) into base SI units:

<Callout emoji="ðŸ’¡">
  In this section, the square brackets around a quantity are used to denote the
  units of that quantity.
</Callout>

$$
\begin{align}
\text{resultant force} &= \text{mass} \times \text{acceleration} \\
\Sigma F &= m \times a \\
[F] &= \text{kg} \times \text{ms}^2
\end{align}
$$

&#8756; If the SI unit for force is Newton, the equivalent unit in terms of **base** SI units is kgms<sup>-2</sup>.

Electrical current, $I$, is defined by the equation, $I = \frac{Q}{t}$, where $Q =$ charge, $t =$ time. The SI unit for charge is the coulomb, C. To express this unit in terms of base SI units, rearrange the equation to make $Q$ the subject.

$Q = I \times t$<span style={{ paddingLeft: 24 }} />&#8756; [Q] = [I] $\times$ [t] $= A \times s$<span style={{ paddingLeft: 24 }} />&#8756; As (Amps seconds)

You are not expected to remember Base SI units, such as the examples shown above &mdash; but you may be asked to derive them.

## Checking equations for homogeneity

Every equation in physics is homogeneous.

An equation is said to be **homogeneous** if **both sides have identical base SI units**.

#### Example

Show that the equation, $v=u+at$, is homogenous

<Columns left="where,">
$v$ = final velocity

$u$ = initial velocity

$a$ = acceleration

$t$ = time

</Columns>

<Columns left={<>
<p>Unit of LHS:</p>
<p>Unit of RHS:</p>
</>}>
ms<sup>-1</sup>

ms<sup>-1</sup> $+$ ms<sup>-2</sup> $\times$ s

ms<sup>-1</sup> $+$ ms<sup>-1</sup>

ms<sup>-1</sup>

</Columns>

LHS units = RHS units &#8756; the equation is homogeneous.

## Scalar and vector quantities

**Scalar** &mdash; a quantity that has magnitude only. _e.g. mass, distance, volume, density, time, speed, pressure_

**Vector** &mdash; a quantity that has magnitude and direction. _e.g. displacement, velocity, acceleration, momentum, force, current_

#### Displacement

Displacement is the vector equivalent of distance. However, it is measured in a different way &mdash; displacement is akin to the 'distance as the crow flies'.

#### Speed and velocity

Velocity is the vector equivalent of speed. However, velocity is defined as **displacement per unit time** and so displacement values must be used to calculate velocity, whereas distance values are used to calculate speed.

### Adding vectors

Vectors can be added or substracted graphically or mathematically.

A **resultant vector** is a combination of multiple vectors added or subtracted.

#### Exapmle 1 &mdash; 'in line' vectors

_A woman is rowing against the flow in a slow moving river and wants to estimate how long the journey will take. To do this she needs an idea of her speed relative to the river bank. She knows her usual rowing speed is 3.2 ms<sup>-1</sup>. The speed of the water in the river is approximately 0.8 ms<sup>-1</sup> in the opposite direction. Calculate her resultant velocity (relative to the river bank)._

Resultant velocity, $v = 3.2 - 0.8 = 2.4$ ms<sup>-1</sup> &xrarr;

#### Example 2 &mdash; not 'in line' vectors

Vectors that are not 'in line' &mdash; i.e. are at a right angle to each other &mdash; can also be added. This can be done by scale drawing or, more accurately, using trigonometry.

<Callout emoji="âœï¸">
  You are only expected to do calculations with vectors that are at 90&deg; to
  each other.
</Callout>

_Imagine a heavy block being pulled by two people simultaneously. Person A pulls with a force of 300N due east; person B pulls with a force of 400N due north. Calculate the resultant force on the block?_

The forces are added by placing them "tip to tail".

The resultant is then the line that joins the tail of one to the tip of the other.

The magnitude of the resultant, $|R|$ can be found using pythagoras, where:

$$
\begin{align}
R^2 &= 300^2 + 400^2 \\
R&= \sqrt{300^2+400^2} \\
|R|&= 500 \text{ N}
\end{align}
$$

The direction of the resultant is given by right-angled trigonometry.

$$
\begin{align}
\tan{\theta} &= \frac{400}{300} \\
\theta &= \tan^{-1}{\frac{400}{300}} \\
&= 53.1^{\circ}
\end{align}
$$

### Subtracting vectors

Sometimes, it is necessary to calculate the 'change' in a certain quantity. A change in a quantity is always the final value, subtract the initial value, and hence this requires vector subtraction.

For example, when calculating acceleration, we need to find the change in velocity.

#### Example

_If a particle is initially travelling to the right with a velocity, $u$, of 25 ms<sup>-1</sup>, but that some time later has a final velocity, $v$, of 10 ms<sup>-1</sup> downwards, we could calculate the change in velocity like this:_

$$
\begin{align}
\Delta v &= v - (+u)  \\
&= v-u
\end{align}
$$

$$
\begin{align}
\Delta v &= 10 - 25 \\
&= -15 \text{ ms}^{-1}
\end{align}
$$

### Resolving vectors

When a vetor is **resolved**, it is split up into vectors that have the same effect as the original. The two new vectors, called **components**, are chosen to be at 90&deg; to each other so that the two components can be treated **independently**.

_Consider a force, $F$, acting at 30&deg; to the horizontal. This force vector can be resolved into two perpendicular components._

These components can be found by simply applying right-angled trigonometry.

#### Calculate:

1. the component perpendicular to the slope, $W_P$
2. the downslope component of the weight, $W_D$

Firstly, identify the angle, $N$, as 25&deg;. (Look at the right-angled triangle in the diagram). We see that the $W_P$ component is linked to the original via the angle, and hence:

$$
\begin{align}
W_P &= W \cos{25} = 30\cos{25} &= 27.2\text{ N} \\
W_D &= W\sin{25} = 30\sin{25} &= 12.7\text{ N}
\end{align}
$$

<Callout emoji="âš¡ï¸">
  Remember &mdash; the original vector always forms the hypotenuse of the new
  triangle formed with the two components.
</Callout>

## Moments

A moment is defined as the product of force and the perpendicular distance between the line of action of the force and the pivot.

The moment is also referred to as the turning effect of a force or the torque.

$$
\text{moment} = \text{force} \times \text{distance}
$$

$$
M = Fd
$$

The units of moment (or torque) are N m.

#### Example 1

Find the moment of the force, $F$, about the point $A$.

$$
\text{moment} = Fd\sin{\theta}
$$

### The principle of moments

For a system to be in equilibrium, the sum of the anticlockwise moments about a point is equal to the sum of the clockwise moments about the same point.

<Callout emoji="ðŸ’¡">
  If an object is in equilibrium, then the resultant moment about any point is
  zero.
</Callout>

This is called the **principle of moments**. The principle of moments can be used to find an unknown force or distance.

#### Conditions needed for equilibrium

1. The resultant force (in any given line) is zero.
2. The net moment (about any point) is zero.

#### Example

_The uniform see-saw shown in the diagram below is pivoted at its mid-point and is in equilibrium. Find the size of the force, $F$._

$$
\begin{align}
\text{total anticlockwise moment} &= \text{total clockwise moment} \\
F \times 0.25 &= \left(1 \times 0.20 \right) + \left(2 \times 0.40\right) \\
F \times 0.25 &= 1.00 \\
F &= 4 \text{ N}
\end{align}
$$

### Centre of gravity

This is the point at which all of the object is considered to act, and makes calculations like those seen above much easier. You need to know the following three examples:

### Centre of gravity and stability

One example of the usefulness of the idea of a centre of gravity is when trying to evaluate the stability of an object, i.e. its toppling angle.

A tilted object will topple over when its weight (acting from the centre of gravity) acts just outside the corner of the object. This is explained in terms of moments.

#### Example

The block is **stable** as the line from the centre of gravity, $C$ _vertically downwards_, passes **through the base** of the block.

The block is now **unstable** and will topple. This is because the line from the centre of gravity, $C$ _vertically downwards_, passes **outside of the base**.

## Density

Density is defined as the mass per unit volume:

$$
\text{density} = \frac{\text{mass}}{\text{volume}}
$$

$$
\rho = \frac{m}{V}
$$

The denser an object with fixed volume is, the more mass it has. The denser an object with fixed mass, the smaller its volume.

Density is measured in the units kgm<sup>-3</sup> or kilograms per cubic metre.

- [Determination of unknown masses by using the principle of moments](/subjects/physics/practicals/u101-e2)
